Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Plasma-Platelet-RBC Ratios in Emergency Laparotomy

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial, severely injured patients predicted to need massive transfusion were enrolled at 12 level I North American trauma centers

Participants.evidence: severely injured patients predicted to need massive transfusion were enrolled at 12 level I North American trauma centers

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive a 1:1:1 or 1:1:2 ratio

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates its effect on survival after emergency laparotomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was survival at 24 hours and 30 days post-emergency laparotomy

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 680 patients were randomised, with 338 assigned to the 1:1:1 group and 342 to the 1:1:2 group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 24-hour survival rate was 86.8% for the 1:1:1 group and 83.1% for the 1:1:2 group (p=0.29), while the 30-day survival rate was 79.3% for the 1:1:1 group and 75.0% for the 1:1:2 group (p=0.30).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were observed between the groups.
